title.narrative: Providing WASH durable solutions to people in need in hard to reach and under-served areas in Nangarhar and Takhar provinces.

description.narrative:
Afghanistan continues to be in a protracted and complex emergency situation with multifaceted conflicts and recurrent natural disasters. As a result, most communities have low resilience and high vulnerability. At the onset of a shock, vulnerable populations often fall into a state of acute emergency, and need support to meet their immediate basic needs. The cumulative impacts of decades of war, natural disasters and chronic poverty, depleted the people’s capacity to cope with repeated shocks. This is combined with the fact that Afghanistan remains one of the most dangerous countries in the world for humanitarians and the delivery of assistance continues to be delayed by access restrictions.
With the support from UNOCHA’s 1st Standard Allocation 2020 and in line with the HRP and the WASH Cluster’s targets, DACAAR will respond to the WASH needs in 5 districts of 2 provinces (3 districts in Nangarhar, 2 districts in Takhar) by constructing wells and a pipe scheme, rehabilitating water points, as well as providing hygiene education in a safe and gender-appropriate manner. Those interventions will address critical WASH needs for all kinds of shock-affected people and contribute to save their lives, as well as increase the resilience and living standards of the most vulnerable affected by protracted crisis. Activities are designed to decrease the spread of water-borne diseases while simultaneously allowing beneficiaries to maintain their health and dignity.
In specific, DACAAR will construct 80 new tube wells (20 in Nangarhar and 60 in Takhar province) fitted with hand pumps delivering safe water for 1,200 families for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene. DACAAR will build 1 water pipe scheme with 150 household connections which will provide safe drinking water to 220 families in Pachir Wagam district of Nangarhar province. The water pipe scheme includes a production well, an elevated water tank, a solar powered water pump and a pipe system that delivers the water to each household. A Water Management Committee will be established to ensure long-term sustainability. In addition, DACAAR will rehabilitate 230 non-functional water points (130 in Nangarhar and 100 in Takhar) for approximate 2,760 families.
Equally important, DACAAR will distribute 1,420 hygiene kits alongside hygiene education to 1,420 families. Hygiene promotion is an integral part of every WASH intervention in order to reduce the risk of water-borne diseases by building the knowledge of safe hygiene behavior. Beneficiaries will receive education on safe drinking water, adequate sanitation, safe food handling, personal and family hygiene.
The estimated direct beneficiaries are 29,260 individuals (4,180 families): 14,560 in Nangarhar and 14,700 in Takhar province. DACAAR will coordinate with the WASH Cluster, UNOCHA, local and government stakeholders, other implementing partners, Protection Cluster, Humanitarian Access Group, etc. on project design, implementation, access, security and on any necessary revisions.
